sightsee_1.name: Zur Tini, Oberammergau, Germany
sightsee_1.description: Oberammergau is a charming Bavarian town, known for its fairy tale frescoes, woodcarvers and Passion Play productions.

sightsee_2.name: Terasa Doamnei, Bucharest
sightsee_2.description: Guts and gore in Bucharest: Dracula's Fillet (pork with hot sauce); brains fried in omelette; grilled spleen; sour tripe soup - traditional Romanian restaurant Terasa Doamnei might not be for the faint of heart, but the menu is a thrill for the taste buds.

sightsee_3.name: Shia Wong Hip Snake Restaurant
sightsee_3.description: Slither over to Shia Wong Hip, which has been serving up snake specialities in Hong Kong since 1965 - the signature snake soup comprises five types of snakes in a thick, warming broth traditionally believed to bolster the body, especially for winter.

sightsee_4.name: Bugs Cafe: Siem Reap, Cambodia
sightsee_4.description: Confront your creepy-crawly fears at Bugs Cafe, where the menu consists entirely of six-and-eight-legged creatures.

sightsee_5.name: Dinner: Viwa Island Resort, Fiji
sightsee_5.description: Dinner on the beach, under a canopy of stars, is one of Viwa Island Resort's highlights, with a Fijian feast of lobster, fish and prawns available to accompany the evening.

sightsee_6.name: Lunch: Viwa Island Resort, Fiji
sightsee_6.description: Lunch at Fiji's Viwa Island Resort is a calm, cheerful affair of carrot salads and fish curries - wholesome, vibrant nourishment after a morning spent visiting the exuberant schoolchildren of a remote village on Fiji's westernmost island in the South Pacific Ocean.

sightsee_7.name: Alfred, Oslo
sightsee_7.description: Named for Alfred Nobel, the resident cafe of Oslo's Nobel Peace Centre is a placid stop for a sandwich of Norwegian smoked trout bolstered by butter from Raros, Snofrisk cream cheese, caraway and capers.

sightsee_8.name: Alex Sushi, Oslo
sightsee_8.description: Seafood is such a staple in Oslo, so it's no surprise that Japanese sashimi joints are serious business here, from relatively traditional restaurants like Alex Sushi, where nigiri is draped in substantial cuts of salmon, halibut, hamachi, sea bass, bluefin tuna and scampi, alongside a glorious gunkan topped with ikura and a quail egg yolk.
